Posts.Content: Jun 14, 2011 05:56PM windlass wrote: I'm in the current "early stage" TDM1 trial. I had my first infusion last week. I believe I got every one of the side effects, which I was told would be "mild." Blinding headache, excruciating back ache, "fatigue" (debilitating exhaustion), flu-like symptoms, lack of appetite - yecch. After groaning in agony from the headache and back ache on Day 1, I slept for 36 hours straight Days 2-3. It's worth every bit of it if it keeps the cancer at bay, though.

Posts.Content: Apr 4, 2012 09:05AM windlass wrote: I had the boosts, and my skin did great. I just posted elsewhere that I attribute my great skin condition to 500 mg of Resveratrol daily. There is great research on resveratrol helping you survive rads and potentiating the effects of rads against the cancer. I'm glad my skin did well enough to handle the boost, considering my IIIC edge-of-the-cliff status.

Posts.Content: Jan 16, 2012 07:40AM windlass wrote: Hi, quiche:  You have to first post the photos on another website, and then link to them from there. It can be any other website, as long as it has a URL. Jenny's photo, for example, is posted at lh3.googleusercontent.com/-xrH...  and then BCO gets it from there. Once you have your photo on another website, click the gree tree icon above to insert an image. It will ask you for the URL. Once you fill it in, you can change the size if you like, and voila!

Posts.Content: Mar 15, 2012 06:28AM windlass wrote: One more tip for the unfuly chem curls is extra-hold mousse. I put it in when my hair is wet, comb it into a manageable style and let it air dry. Then eventually, when I think about it, I run my fingers through my hair to break up the crusty feeling of the dried mousse, and viola, my hair is soft and well styled. Robo47: I wish I had the guts to post photos here. My hair was that short last summer, and I have photos of me at the beach that are just shudderable, compared to now. Hang in there, in a few months you will have what looks like "intentional" hair. *hugs*

Posts.Content: Mar 18, 2011 08:36PM windlass wrote: geocachelinda: YAY! Our cancer has not spread!!! You and I have been neck and neck on just about everything. I had a very stressful day of waiting for test results, just like you, and then I was also told that the cancer had not spread beyond my awful lymph nodes.What an enormous relief! I bet you were doing the happy dance. I sure was!! What did you think of the CT scan and bone scans? The bone scan was the weirdest, since I was radioactive for 24 hours after it. Creepy, with all we're hearing about Japan at the same time. I start 4 cycles of AC (Adriamycin and Cytoxane) next week, then because my tumor was HER2 positive, I get 4 cycles of Herceptin and Taxol. I have the option of doing a clinical trial for an experimental HER2 drug that shows a lot of promise and I signed up for that instead of the H/T regimen. Now to see if I get in. Like you, I also get 30 rads, and long term hormone control. Plus 17 additional herceptin treatments over a year's time. Anyone had their chemo port installed yet?
Posts.Title: February 2011 Mastectomy texasrose361 TinaT

Posts.Content: Mar 25, 2011 09:43PM - edited Mar 26, 2011 11:56PM by windlass Hi, Kimmysu: So sorry to hear about all your pain! My advice would be to get a referral to see your hospital physical therapist ASAP. My hospital has one who specializes in mastectomy patients, and she has helped me with mobility, tips to prevent lymphedema, mobilizing the fluid so you don't get a seroma, and more. I can't say enough good about meeting with her! She is even helping me keep the skin from adhering and the scar from tightening. I meet with her once a week. She wants to see me for 8 visits. As for the radiation, everything I've heard says that radiation actually dulls pain. I guest it sort of shorts out the nerve endings temporarily, which should help with what you're feeling.  Have you already had the chemotherapy? Did they do that first, as neo-adjuvant therapy? My thoughts and prayers are with you!
Posts.Title: February 2011 Mastectomy texasrose361 TinaT

Posts.Content: Feb 13, 2012 05:09PM - edited Feb 13, 2012 05:13PM by windlass Ana: No, I was not offended at all! Seriously. The whole weird turn this thread took just got me to thinking that I really DON'T feel like I know my body. In fact, I'm feeling kind of betrayed by it, and wondering if its my fault or my body's. Or maybe it's the fault of both of us for not having a better relationship. I'm an "in-my-head" kind of gal, and sometimes this body of mine just feels like a gallumphing, needy prison, or a demanding fair-weather friend that could snuff me out if I don't continually appease it. I probably need to start thinking of my body as the temple of the Holy Spirit if I am ever going to overcome that. I totally get where you were coming from, and what you said made perfect common sense. I'm sorry people took offense, because it was clear none was intended.  I wonder if we big tumor gals are thin-skinned about "Why didn't you find it?!?" type questions because we have asked ourselves that same question so many times - and not always in a kind way. That's obviously not what you asked or said, Ana. But it might explain why everyone here feels a little bit jittery. I mean really, why the hell DIDN'T we find these nasty, killer tumors when they were tiny little lentils like everyone else? Then we could be the Good Prognosis stage 1 gals instead of the poster children for everyone's head shaking and chiding comments.  ("You know, if you had detected that earlier...") You just got caught in our own internal crossfire.  Warm hugs to you, Ana. And I'm glad your emu oil is fresh! I feel ripped off by mine, but think it still worked wonders.
Posts.Title: Calling All with Tumors 6 cm + J-Bug CaliKelly

Posts.Content: Feb 13, 2012 06:37PM - edited Feb 13, 2012 06:38PM by windlass It's been a long time since I had had so much fun doing anything as I did posting on this BCO thread. For the last few days I felt like a happy, giggly teenager, instead of a sick, discouraged, overweight, limping, pain-wracked, middle aged, "poor prognosis" cancer patient. But today, instead of laughing, I spent at least an hour crying. I snapped at my husband. I shooed away my kids. And I still feel like crap. Just posting here now has me crying all over again. The silence here these last five hours is a complete and total bummer for all of us who had bonded over an important problem/challenge/opportunity regarding sex - an issue that we all share or we wouldn't be posting here. And given the topic, it's a bummer especially for our husbands. (Er, I suppose I should say our gender neutral "partners." But give me a freaking break. This thread is about PENISES AND VAGINAS. Who's going to be able to avoid being "sexist" when discussing that??) Maybe some happier person, with thicker skin, who is allowed to post on here, can say something to bring back the joy of this thread. I'll just sit on the sidelines and root for you.
Posts.Title: SEX - Very Raw Post cancerkicker Moderators

Posts.Content: Feb 8, 2011 06:05PM - edited Feb 8, 2011 06:06PM by windlass This is my first post here. Thanks for all the encouragement in your posts. I opted to wait before getting a reconstruction, though I wonder if I'll have the guts to go through surgery twice. You all seem so chipper and positive. I have my good days when I am optimistic and feel like I can take on the world, but to be honest, I'm feeling pretty awful about the whole thing tonight.

Posts.Content: Mar 5, 2011 10:16PM windlass wrote: I want to strongly recommend a book called "Natural Strategies for Cancer Patients," by Russell Blaylock. It is the best book on nutrition and strategies to fight cancer and prevent recurrence that I have read (and I must own more than 20 cancer books at this point). He cites solid research (and tons of it) drawing a clear connection between nutrition and cancer prevention. You are what you eat, and if you eat right, you'll have a good chance of beating the cancer and keeping it from returning.

Posts.Content: Feb 25, 2011 08:41AM windlass wrote: I made it safely through my MX on Tuesday (I'm a 2/22), and am home recuperating. The surgery part was actually easy since I wasn't really there for it and I don't remember anything at all. They wheeled me into the operating room, I was joking with the nurses, then the next thing I remember I was waking up with my surgeon telling me everything had gone well. The bad news is that the surgeon had to take ALL of my lymph nodes (!!) so my staging just got much worse. I'm trying not to stress about mets. (Not that I have any symptoms of metasteses, but I'm still pretty scared.) I won't get the pathology report til the end of next week. HERKY: I loved the WINE RACK, hahaha, so glad we can still laugh. Sending love and well wishes to XMASDX, DONNAJT, and  REDSKYATNIGHT - you'll do great and it will be over in no time! The anticipation was a thousand times worse than the actual surgery.
Posts.Title: February 2011 Mastectomy texasrose361 TinaT

Posts.Content: Feb 27, 2011 07:42AM windlass wrote: Today is my 5th day post-surgery and things are going well - physically at least. No sign of infection, and I am off all the pain meds. I only used Vicodin three days then ibuprofin yesterday morning, and today I am pain-free and pain-med-free. There's just a little burning around the incision site if I move too much. Since I did not do a reconstruction, things may be healing faster. One weird thing is I noticed my face had a scary greenish cast to it yesterday, and when I looked at my lower eyelids, they were very pale. My kind husband made me a hearty meal last night, and I ate red meat for the first time since my diagnosis six weeks ago. (I've been eating like an organic rabbit, with gallons of fresh, raw veggie juices, and only occasional wild caught salmon or organic chichen for protein.) I think it helped to get some iron back into my body. I feel much better today. My husband helped me with a sponge bath yesterday which made me feel like an invalid or a little kid, but I also felt loved. We tried to scrub my underarms (uggh), and when hit hit the MX side I screamed! Somehow since there's no incision there, I thought that part was intact. But duh, the surgeon took all my lymph nodes so obviously that was going to hurt. I guess they must take them from underneath, since there's no bandage on my underarm. The incision is way lower on my body, under all these tightly wrapped bandages, in the middle of where my breast used to be. Since I can't really get my underarm clean, and I have been told not to use powders or lotions or deodorant, I feel (and smell) like a construction worker who hasn't hit the shower in a few days. It will be a relief to get the drains out and take a real, hot, soapy shower. Did they also tell you gals no shaving with a razor? One more strange new change to come: Getting an electric shaver. Geocache Linda: I am so sorry to hear about your infection! Please let us know how it goes after Monday's visit. I know you and I are part of the small group here that did not opt for an immediate reconstruction. Considering the trouble with our lymph nodes, it was probably a wise decision for us both to delay the reconstruction. I hope you have no regrets. (I had quite a few second thoughts until after the surgery when I learned about the nodes.) I'll be praying for you and following your progress as you post here.  Much love to all the Feb 2011 gals as we mourn and celebrate the various ups and downs of this trial. Breast cancer is a real game changer, isn't it!
Posts.Title: February 2011 Mastectomy texasrose361 TinaT

Posts.Content: Jul 21, 2011 11:44PM windlass wrote: So I am Stage III, with a large tumor, and positive receptors, and not that far off from your mom's age. There you will get a proper, aggressive treatment plan. Stage III cancer is not something you screw around with. You throw everything in the book at it.

Posts.Content: Feb 10, 2011 08:02AM windlass wrote: ChrissyMH: You posted that you wanted to go back for a mastectormy after your lumpectomy and would your insurance pay for it. I was surprised, but one of the books I read said a mastectomy is WAY cheaper than a lumpectomy, which is apparently why some insurers try to talk you into a mastectomy. I guess it's easier to takeoff everything than delicately wield the scalpel trying to get only the cancer and leave the rest intact. I hope your insurance company gives you the green light, but if not, you may want to consider paying for it out of pocket. When I asked what my mastectomy would cost if I paid for it myself,  I was told between $3,000 and $7,500 if there's no reconstruction. That seems pretty cheap for a major surgery, anaesthesia, and two nights in the hospital. If your insurance won't pay it, you could practically put that on a credit card. Good luck!
Posts.Title: February 2011 Mastectomy texasrose361 TinaT

Posts.Content: Feb 21, 2011 12:16PM windlass wrote: Just two days left to go. I am working to remember that the goal of this surgery is to get the cancer out, not to remove my breast. Thinking of it that way makes it easier.  Given that I already have cancer, the surgery is a GOOD THING.
Posts.Title: February 2011 Mastectomy texasrose361 TinaT

Posts.Content: Mar 2, 2011 10:53PM - edited Mar 2, 2011 10:54PM by windlass Waterless, showerless, deodorant-less, underarm cleaning Before I got my drains out, I invented a great way to do a "sponge bath" that removes underarm odor without using soap and water. It really works, and best of all, it doesn't cause pain for those of us who had a lot of surgery on the lymph nodes. I'm passing it along for all the gals whose drains are still in. * Lie down with a hand towel under one armpit. (You may want to ask your husband or a friend to help, esp if you had a bilateral.) * Sprinkle baking soda liberally all over the underarm, going a few inches beyond where you would normally apply deodorant. Rub it around, then brush it gently off onto the towel. Repeat. There will still be odor - but don't worry. * You can remain lying down or you can sit up for this step. Take a flat, eyemakeup-remover-type cotton pad and wet it with hydrogen peroxide. Rub it across the underarm. Repeat until all smell is gone. Viola! That's all you have to do. It leaves you smelling clean and fresh without a trace of odor. I was amazed at how well this works.
Posts.Title: February 2011 Mastectomy texasrose361 TinaT

Posts.Content: Mar 3, 2011 08:07AM - edited Mar 3, 2011 08:16AM by windlass Hi, JackieMom - welcome to our little group! TexasRose - can you add Jackie to our February victory-over-surgery list? Seeay: You and I are the Grade 3, triple positive gals, though it looks like you caught yours a lot sooner than I caught mine. You asked about post-surgical treatment. I think they have me lined up for 4 months of "standard" chemo, a year of herceptin for the Her2+, and 5, 10, 15 (?) years of hormone blockers (most likely tamoxifen) for the ER+. I'll be starting near the end of the month. As for lymphatic massage, I've been scared to even touch my lymph system for fear it would spread the cancer. Maybe post surgery it's okay? Oh, and I did get a bra today with the temporary, post-surgery "puff" made out of styrofoam beanbag type filling (the tiny balls). I also ordered two lacy, floral bras that will be here next week. When I have them on, you can literally not tell which side got MX'ed!
Posts.Title: February 2011 Mastectomy texasrose361 TinaT

Posts.Content: Dec 31, 2011 09:46AM windlass wrote: I have a question for everyone. Considering how huge our tumors were, how did we not notice them? I'd like to hear your stories. Here is mine: When i was nursing, my breasts would lump up all the time, so I got used to feeling big lumps in them that would come and go. Trouble is, it had been a year and a half since I'd stopped nursing, so you'd think I might have figured out those lumps should have been gone by then. Weirdly, they sort of DID come and go, though, with my cycle. The primary tumor, 5 cm, would soften and harden throughout the month. So I just assumed it was hormonal. Big mistake!

Posts.Content: Feb 10, 2011 07:33AM windlass wrote: Thanks for the warm welcome, Tina and Cameron! And thanks for the tip, Kezzie, I am having my surgery at Dana Farber too (on Feb 22) and will check out the camisols.I love my surgeon there. I went to my local hospital's support group last night and had a wonderful experience. There were about a dozen women there and most were celebrating several years of being cancer-free. I thought it would be a depressing woe-fest, but it was just the opposite. They were welcoming and happy to answer all my questions like a warm cluck of happy hens. It helped to meet other women face to face who have gone through this and come out well and happy on the other side. The weird part was being the youngest woman in the room. At age 44 I've stopped thinking of myself as young, but in the breast cancer context the docs and specialists keep saying I am. (Hey, I'll take my consolation wherever I can find it.)  There were only two other women in their 40's, but everyone else was older. From what I've read elsewhere on this discussion board, this online crowd may be a bit younger. How old is everybody here? 20's, 30's, 40's, 50's, 60's,70's, beyond? Blessings and calm and healing and strength to us all as we face our surgeries this month.

Posts.Content: windlass wrote: If a woman has a large tumor with a lot of lymph node involvement, but gets a clean bone scan, and her lungs and liver are clear, can she get spine or brain mets while in treatment? I know someone who is on chemo, and in the middle of it she's started having unilateral numbness and tingling in her right arm combined with a lot of mental instability. The chiropractor and massage therapist confirm the numbness and tingling are coming from the neck and spine (they call it "compression" and say there is a tight muscle mass squeezing the nerve), and the oncs say the confusion is "just" chemobrain plus the result of hormonal changes. My question is this - Could this be mets, and can a person get brain mets, spinal mets, or other CNS mets while they're in the thick of their first rounds of chemo treatments? "He will cover you with his feathers, and under his wings you will find refuge." -Psalm 91 . . . . . . Completed: UniMX, DIEP reconstr; A/C x 4; TDM1 x 4; Taxotere+Herceptin x 4, 33 Rads; TDM1 Phase II Trial x 9; Tamoxifen, prayer. Brain Mets 2015. Dx 1/18/2011, IDC, 6cm+, Stage IV, metastasized to brain, Grade 3, 12/28 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2+ Radiation Therapy Breast, Lymph nodes Log in to post a reply

Posts.Title: Calling All with Tumors 6 cm + J-Bug CaliKelly

Posts.Content: Jan 16, 2012 03:48AM - edited Jan 16, 2012 03:53AM by windlass Speaking of large tumors, I just realized something that would be obvious if you were calculating volumes in 10th grade geometry, but hadn't occurred to me with regard to our tumors:  Namely a 6 cm tumor is not merely six times bigger than a 1 cm tumor. Assuming that both tumors are roughly spherical, a 6 cm tumor is actually 217 times bigger than a 1 cm tumor! Don't believe me? Try the math yourself here:  www.calculateme.com/cVolume/Vo...  That's a major mind blower. I couldn't find a chart on the 'net with spheres to compare, but I did find this childbirth dilation chart that gives a sense of just how huge a 6 or 7 cm tumor really is - at least in two dimensions. Six to seven centimeters is like a tennis ball. And you ladies with 10 cm tumors basically had grapefruit sized tumors (!)
Posts.Title: Calling All with Tumors 6 cm + J-Bug CaliKelly

Posts.Content: Dec 23, 2011 11:08PM windlass wrote: I'm in this club too. I had a 13 cm "area of involvement," in which the largest single tumor was 5 cm. Apparently the entire lower half of my left breast was a cancer-riddled mess. My breast surgeon was a little freaked after my sugery. When she described the state of my lymph nodes, she said several of them were no longer even identifiable as lymph nodes since they were pure cancer.  I was scared to death when they did the numerous scans to stage me and see if the cancer had spread, but by the grace of God and lots of prayer, my scans were clean. My heart goes out to all my sisters waiting for scan results.
Posts.Title: Calling All with Tumors 6 cm + J-Bug CaliKelly

Posts.Content: Feb 16, 2012 03:05PM - edited Feb 16, 2012 03:06PM by windlass I'd like to ask BCO's moderators to revise the tumor size setting to include larger tumors, rather than simply lumping us off into "6cm+" (Ack, forgive that awful, unintentional pun!) I know BCO is planning changes to the site and that they are accepting suggestions. Would this be a good one? Or would you gals prefer to stay in the nebulous zone? My own tumor was a series of "skip lesions" that measured a horrific 13 cm (more than five inches) which was pretty much the entire lower half of my B-cup breast. But the largest single tumor I had was 5 cm, so that's what I put in my signature. (Haha, that's what I tell myself to stay calm, actually.)  I might put 13 cm if I had that option, if for no other reason than to stimulate discussion, since the things we large-tumor gals have to contribute are important to this community at large. I submitted some other suggestions to the mods, and have a contact if we want to ask for the size choices to expand upward. Opinions?

I hope yours do likewise.

Posts.Content: Jan 28, 2012 10:17AM windlass wrote: I didnt' have neoadjuvant chemo (chemo before my mastectomy), so there was no chance for anything to shrink before my surgery. When my cancer was diagnosed, neither my oncologists nor my surgeon through my lymph nodes were involved. Once they got in there with the surgery, however, they found that the sentinel lymph node was a mess, so they kept going. By the time they were done, they had found twelve cancerous lymph nodes that were so cancer-ridden they no longer even resembled lymph nodes. My surgeon went on to remove all 28 lymph nodes, and was pretty freaked out when she got the pathology report. (I love her, btw - she's the greatest.) I tell you all of this only to say that when the experts palpate your underarm and say they don't feel anything it's not a guarantee there's no cancer there.

Posts.Content: Jan 4, 2012 05:03PM windlass wrote: I (and several other scared ladies) found this reply from LuluBee to be very helpful in a similar circumstance. She wrote it in response to a post I had started asking if there were other Stage IIIC women out there who had done herceptin and developed mets. Nov 11, 2011 09:04 pm lulubee wrote: Windlass and all, What we Stage IV sisters have learned from one another's stories is that there's no rhyme or reason to this disease, and no way to know what is coming next. Ever since I went directly from Stage I NED to Stage IV, I find I do not have the heart to tell my story anywhere on these boards anymore except in the Stage IV forums-- out of compassion for the lower stage ladies. I think when we Stage IV ladies engage with those of you who still have a chance to LIVE through this, we feel an urge to protect your hearts from the heaviness ours now must carry. We would all urge you to be fierce about protecting your hope-- and listening to our dark stories is not likely to help you keep your head in the light. Honestly, the only advice I have to give you is that I regret every single cotton-picking minute I ever spent at Stage I worrying about what was coming next. I wish to God now that I had every one of those minutes back. I would spend them playing with my kids, smiling at my husband, holding babies, and eating lots of pie on picnic blankets with all my best beloveds. I really am sorry if we Stage IV gals seem clique-ish at times. It's largely because we share a peculiar wisdom that we have gained while walking through the valley of the shadow of death. And that wisdom has made us abundantly compassionate and protective toward women who haven't had to join our clique. We hope you never do. We want you to LIVE. Peace to you-- ~lulubee
Posts.Title: People are un-freaking believe-able... Sido PizzaDad

Posts.Content: Apr 12, 2012 02:38PM windlass wrote: Hi, StrongOne, what a great name you've chosen! This is going to be a battle for your mom, and she is blessed to have a daughter like you to support and care about her. The "stage" of a cancer depends on the size of the tumor, and how far it has spread. You can find details here: http://www.breastcancer.org/symptoms/diagnosis/staging.jsp As for a second opinion, I would strongly recommend getting a treatment plan from a research cancer center. Here is a list: http://cancercenters.cancer.gov/cancer_centers/cancer-centers-list2.html  These centers can offer your mom experimental, state-of-the-art treatments that will not be available at your local hospital.  Research has shown that people who travel more than 50 miles for their cancer treatment have a better outcome than those who don't, most likely because they are leaving the corner hospital for somewhere  more cutting edge. I hope this helps. Feel free to private message me with your phone number if you'd like to talk by phone. Warm hugs, Windlass
